item.title: Causal inference throughout the statistics curriculum
item.description: Slides ASA Joint Statistical Meetings 2022 • Washington, D.C. • August 10, 2022 Abstract: Causal questions abound in everyday life, but the rote mantra of "Correlation does not imply causation" that is routinely taught in statistics courses leaves students wanting.

item.title: A metabolic view of symptoms in kidney disease
item.description: Slides Applied Probability and Statistics seminar • University of St. Thomas • April 1, 2022 Abstract: Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease commonly experience debilitating symptoms, but the toxins that cause these symptoms are unknown.

item.title: What did I just read?
item.description: Slides Women in Analytics and Data Science • Minne Analytics • October 30, 2020 Abstract: Staying up to date on the relevant results and methodology in our fields is crucial for doing our best work but can be challenging if the literature is vast.

item.title: Graphs Galore! Representing Knowledge in the Sciences and Humanities
item.description: Slides Statistics seminar • Carleton College • October 22, 2019 Abstract: Knowledge moves forward by a continual integration of existing ideas with new findings.

item.title: Statistical methods for querying the regulatory role of DNA
item.description: Slides Dept. of Mathematics Colloquium • Creighton University • March 22, 2019 Abstract: DNA is often called the blueprint for life because it encodes the information needed for our cells to function.
